Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned, more than anything else, a way to think critically about the role that architecture can play in the social/cultural fabric of cities.
I learned a bit about urban trends in American history.

Learned about the growth and development of cities and architecture in the United States. Also learned about how that influenced and was influenced by social happenings during the time and the current issues that cities face.
How to understand architecture in the context of society and symbolism.
Ability to analyze architectural structures and gain a different perspective on the world around us.

- A breadth of knowledge on American architecture and planning from pre-colonial times all the way to the modern day
- How to interpret a building within its social, economic, and political context
- How to research the history of a building using a wide variety of primary sources, from tax records to phonebooks to insurance maps

Not much really. I learned a bit about the general architectural trends in the US but the material felt random and confusing. There was no core logic to follow through the course leaving me feeling lost and clueless.
Learned 143 American buildings
We learned about the social implications of architectural and city development.

I really enjoyed becoming more observant of the buildings and architecture around me especially in New Haven. I am more equipped to identify buildings and styles and understand the history of American cities through the lens of architectural developments.
American architecture, different types of buildings, the urban fabric of America
I gained a deeper understanding and appreciation of the physical and social history of the built environment around me.
I learned a lot about architecture as a whole that I didn't know about before. Also learned a lot about different buildings around the country and in New Haven.
This course does a great job of engaging students in the built environment. Over the course of the semester, we learned how to read our environment and appreciate the built spaces we occupy.
I learned about the development of American cities and the changes in architecture as well.

Professor Rubin does a fantastic job at making clear how the built environment is informed by the contours of power that underlie it, and it enabled an alternative understanding of political history in the terms of inhabited landscapes.
This course, which is structured chronologically, teaches you about the history and themes of American architecture. Ive developed a familiarity with both buildings and stylesbut to a limited degree.
Na
understanding of different architectural styles, the history behind various urban forms

We learned about how american architecture has changed, starting around the 11th century and ending with the early 2000s.  We learned about different architectural movements, how they were impacted by external events and politics, and  different monumental architects and buildings.

I developed a lot of skills on architecture and how to view the context of buildings and structures. Rather than just focusing on superficial aspects or evoked feelings upon looking at a structure, I learned the importance of historical context.

I gained so much more knowledge on the history of American architecture, and how it impacts and is impacted by so many factors. I learned how to look more closely at buildings, and this is an invaluable skill that is going to be very helpful for me onwards.

Get an overarching idea of the different era/styles, as well as the icon structures, of American architecture. Very interesting material and it's cool to just learn about buildings that you've seen but don't know much about prior

Knowledge of architectural buildings, movements, styles, etc. in connection with American urban growth and history. It is neither a class purely about architecture, nor a class purely about history --- this course is true to its cross-listed status, cross-cutting across disciplines in a manner accessible to all (even those without prior background in any of the academic fields!) by emphasizing themes as opposed to rote memorization of facts. Learned how architectural papers are organized, and even got to try my hand at writing two (one of which was a building research analysis of some building in New Haven --- super fun!) Also learned how to memorize the names, dates, locations, and architects/designers of over a hundred buildings in three days, but I suppose this was a necessary evil.
I developed a keen architectural eye -- I feel like every street in America is more exciting after this class.

Basics of architecture, urban design; how to read buildings, cityscapes, and their environments. I gained a newfound appreciation for New Haven, and was encouraged by this class to move away from campus and look at the city in a new light.
The basic knowledge of architecture. I was able to evaluate buildings and structures and compare them.
Changed the way I looked at cities and buildings. Works on observation skills to pick up when a building was built with what influences through a ton of examples, both famous and mundane.

I learned about architectural trends in America and how they manifest in the built environment today. With the class, I think I go around and look at most buildings in America and have a general sense of when they were built and the intellectual/social trends behind it. We also learned how to describe a building in architectural language.
Learned a lot about different architectural styles throughout American history. Also learned why cities are the way they are, which was cool.

This class is an amazing survey of different periods in American architecture and the urban initiatives that they were associated with. You will develop the ability to critique the architecture and urbanism of the world around you, regardless of what part of country you are from or familiar with. You will also develop a robust understanding of different architectural styles and the rationales for their popularity.

I learned about the history of American architecture and urban development, the history of different architectural styles, and how the needs, issues, and technological developments within American culture influences how people interact with and create the architecture around them as time goes on.
Gained knowledge about the significance of architecture throughout America but also throughout the city of New Haven especially.
More informed perspective on the urban built environment.
A great overview knowledge of the history of American architectural movements
History of American architecture; how to look at and evaluate a building; importance of architecture

An overview of the key themes in Architecture and Urbanism through American history - including social, economic, political, media-related and visual themes. Ways of approaching interpretation of the built environment and critical analysis of how cities came to be the way they are, and who felt the impacts of the building of that environment. In some ways this course provides an overview of US history through the lens of the built environment, and definitely focusses equally as much on social/political/economic forces and movements at play as it does on the physicality and visual part of architectural/urban design.

I developed a greater knowledge and appreciation for Americas architecture and built environment. In addition to my understanding of historical architecture, I now have a more profound appreciation for the various structures of our nation, especially in New Haven.
Learned a lot about the urban landscape. Look at buildings in a new way

I learned about the different architectural movements throughout American history and how they relate/reflect social conditions of the time period. I loved the sociology aspect of architecture and how we looked at so many pictures. I gained a good understanding of how to interpret architecture and to look more closely at the built environment around me.

This class taught me how to appreciate, enjoy, and critique the urban and built environments around me. I pay more careful attention to architectural styles and urban development wherever I go because of this class.
Knowledge concerning the history/evolution of American architecture, as well as the analysis/identification of this architecture.

This course gives a very broad overview of themes, trends, and movements in American architecture (building style) and urbanism (theory of cities) starting with a cursory look at pre-Columbian cultures and ending with contemporary projects. It builds a foundation in the history of architecture in this country, as well as the other historical factors that influence it, including changes in economics, civil rights, and international relations. It also hones skills for visual analysis and architectural writing.
I learned so much about the way that we interact with the built environment and how American urban landscapes developed over time.

I will never look at building the same in America. I was interested in architecture but didn't want to major in it. I now know the history of American Architecture, many notable architects and buildings.

I learned the basics of American architectural history and urbanism. This is definitely a survey course, but it's a good one. I came away from the course with a new understanding of the built environment that I really appreciate.

I really began to consider the buildings that surround me, and I acquired a small bit of the vocabulary that can be used to describe them. I got a rough overview of American architectural history, and I learned the names/dates/architects of some famous/important buildings.

I learned a lot about the foundations of American architecture and urbanism. I knew nothing about architecture before, and now would be able to speak somewhat comfortably about the specific periods of American architecture and their cultural significance.
I learned about a variety of architectural styles, architects, urban forms, and so much more about the politics and social influences that affect the construction of these forms.
American architectural history, visual analytical skills.
This is a strong survey class where you'll get a pretty cursory and broad understanding of the development of American Architecture.

I gained a deeper understanding of the architectural world and an awareness of my surrounding landscape. I am now able to compare different styles and aspects of buildings, as well as understand how a structure plays a role in a community.
I learned about the history of architectural movements as well as some of the history of New Haven architecture.

We learned about the history of architecture and urban planning in the US and how factors like race, gender, and class interacted with those fields. I found this class extremely interesting and eye-opening and it helped me better understand the cities I've lived in. Also you'll learn a ton about New Haven which is really cool.

This class was a great intro to the history of architecture, design, and Urbanism in America. Though its a broad and shallow intro, its was a fantastic way to comprehend broad concepts in design theory.

This was an incredible course. I learned a concise history of American architecture - from early settlements to postmodern architecture. We discussed the forces that shaped the American landscape and the key players. We critiqued buildings and sites on their own terms, far beyond physical appearance or style. We traced buildings over time and analyzed what makes a piece of architecture "good." We spent time discussing the impact of architecture on marginalized communities, and in particular, heritage and dissonant heritage. We spent time talking about the rich architectural fabric of New Haven and used this city as a way to make lectures more concrete. Through the first project, I learned how to trace the history of a building. I've become infinitely more aware of the landscapes I move through and live in, and I have felt a deeper connection to the city of New Haven.
I learned to think critically about how urbanism has helped develop the society we live in.
An ability to read and understand a broad urban landscape, as well as individual buildings and pieces of architecture.

I had never taken a course that discussed the history of American Architecture. I gained so much knowledge about the chronological movements and influences, patrons and architects that resulted in the built environment we have today.
I learned so much about American urban forms. I can now look at buildings and urban layouts and have an understanding of how and why the developed.

I gained the knowledge of how to evaluate my surroundings and analyze architecture that I am already somewhat more familiar with more intentionally. The patterns and forms of architecture and urban planning in the USA has many fascinating aspects and a rich history.

This course gave me the opportunity to learn about different architecture styles, designs, movements and the sociopolitical and economic motivations underlying the formation of the American urban landscape and built environment. Though hands-on projects, I learned how to analyze buildings and try to place them in the context of broader movements in American architecture. It was eye-opening to apply what I learned in class to the built environment of New Haven and see the layers of development in the city that we live in.
I learned to interpret and understand various American urban fabrics. This course made me more aware of the physical and social affects of my surroundings.
I learned to appreciate various buildings that I see.
I learned more about trends and movements in American architecture and city planning.

I developed a broad understanding of historic architectural styles and American urbanism.  This is a class that has changed my perspective on the buildings and cities around me, and has helped me appreciate and question small details in every structure I see.

I learned the trends in the history of American architecture and city planning, from the colonial settlements and towns to modern developments. The course taught me how to research a building, write about architecture/urbanism, and how to analyze buildings and cities in a more nuanced way and being conscious of the historical context.
How to look at and understand the built environment and its connection to social history/social changes

Different architectural movements, styles, influences, etc. Learned how to look at buildings differently and gained a new sense of appreciation for a lot of the buildings in New Haven and cities I visit often like New York.
I left this class with an appreciation for overall themes in American architecture and its history.
how to identify buildings from different time periods and then discuss their features, whether that be in an essay or discussion.
a better understanding of the big picture of american architectural and urban history
Great class for looking at American history from a new perspective.

I learned how to observe and read the built environment better, learned about the general history of urbanism in America, learned some really interesting ways to think about space and some themes across urbanism, and learned about significant buildings/plans/people in American architecture.
I learned a great deal about American architectural structure and history. The course portrayed a cohesive story of American architecture from pre-colonial times to present day.
I felt there could have been more connection between the lectures and the readings.
The lectures are pretty engaging. I enjoyed the research projects. I wish I had learned more about actual architecture--a lot of the "urbanism" elements of the course just felt like AP History.
Was an engaging course even as a STEM major with little to no previous knowledge about architecture.

Professor Rubin definitely tried to make this course more accessible to broader disciplines beyond architecture in his lectures, which was pretty great. I would say a weakness within the sections (maybe it was just the makeup of mine) is that it felt difficult at times to keep up without understanding and knowing architectural terms off the back of your head. The course seems to rely a lot on memorization, which I don't think I was prepared to do. Nevertheless, the professor and TFs seem eager to help.

Strengths:
- Professor Rubin is an INCREDIBLE lecturerpretty much every class would fly
- The class covers a little bit of everything, so things never get stale and there is something for everyone
- Resources on Canvas are well organized
- Professor Rubin provides myriad opportunities to engage with the material outside of class, such as optional sessions at the Beinecke and Manuscripts and Archives looking at old site plans, etc.

Weaknesses:
- lecture itself can sometime feel disorganized and Professor Rubin can go off on tangents where you are unsure whether to take notes or not (though in the end this doesn't really matter because he provides such a detailed study guide for the final and sufficient review sessions that if you missed a few things it's no big deal)

The course has no structure. Professor Rubin is very knowledgeable and is clearly passionate but this means he jumps from topic to topic as he covers too much. I feel like we covered a lot but learned very little.
Lectures are so scattered and then the study guide is jam packed and you have to teach yourself
amazing lectures, covered a lot, and had a clear message the entirety of the course

I think the biggest strength was Elihu Rubin as a lecturer. He obviously cares so much about the subject and the history and his students. His lectures are really interesting and he knows so much about what he's talking about. Weaknesses are that he assigns a ton of reading that's not really possible to get through each week.
The assignments are creative and fun and Professor Rubin is great. The final exam is very difficult and a lot of material to memorize

Strengths: Fascinating lectures. Interesting, meaningful, and manageable assignments. Great professor with wonderful TAs. Crucially important content for the assiduous American citizen.
Weaknesses: Only one little thing...font on Powerpoint slides was oppressively small!
This course gave a great insight into the course of American architecture and urbanism and was well-run both by Elihu and by the TFs.
Elihu is an excellent lecturer and makes the topic more engaging

This course is a great survey that covers a lot of material. It could be improved by either cutting back a tiny bit or giving more time to the lectures because it did constantly feel like we were running out of time.
The class is well-organized and taught very well.

Professor Rubin is visibly passionate about his field and has extensive knowledge of it, which tangibly helps with retaining information.  I would recommend a slightly longer period for the final exam given that the identification questions require far more time than expected.

Strengths: some interesting material; the class teaches you a useful understand of the American built environment; some very interesting lectures.

Weaknesses: an overwhelming number of readings that are only discreetly related to lecture; lectures that can be drawn on unnecessarily; repetitive material at some points; a lack of general definitions of architectural vocabulary and styles that left me confused.
Disorganized lectures
The readings are too extensive, quite difficult to get through all of them. also not clear/methodical enough definition of eras and styles i wouldve liked clearer more structured lectures

strengths: The class material is super interesting, professor Rubin is a great lecturer and really cares about the class, the class isn't too much work, the tfs are supportive and there is a lot of supplemental help for assignments

One strength is the lectures. They are presented in an interesting way and they are very engaging. One weakness might be the lack of assignments. This made preparation for exams more difficult because there was no practice with reviewing the material beforehand.
Strengths were that it was an engaging class. Weakness was that I thought the final exam was kind of ridiculous, but it wasn't that bad when I actually took it.

Interesting material, Lectures are interesting, Section discussions are cool

Could be improved if Prof Rubin made the eras/styles more clear in lecture. It was quite confusing near the end of the semester as the lectures aren't exactly in chronological order

Rubin is an amazing and engaging lecturer who has managed to weave an approachable narrative to the American architectural field. He is a strength, as well as the TA staff who lead riveting discussions based on slide comparisons. Weakness would be the sheer number of images that are presented in the class, and the fact that there is no compiled list of buildings to focus on knowing and understanding until Reading Period, which is a bit too late (there was a class website for images, but it wasn't updated after Lecture 5). There also wasn't much transparency with regards to paper grading criteria, which seemed too dependent on the TA. But, the TAs gave super detailed feedback for the first paper, which helped a lot going into writing the second.

The lectures, projects, and structure of the course are all excellent. It covers every major period of American Architecture thoroughly, exposes every student to archival research at the New Haven Museum, Beinecke, and Manuscripts and Archives, and had a stunning team of TFs. It's difficult to think of any weaknesses of the class -- it's one of my favorite that I've taken at Yale. As a senior, I especially appreciated the chance to learn about the built environment of New Haven before graduating.
Strengths: incredible lecture, fascinating content, very good assignments. Weaknesses: section didn't cover readings.

Strengths: topics, strong lecturer, interesting assignments

Cons: memorization-based final doesn't actually really cover what we learned in class well

I think this class could be treated as a GUT, since there are few graded assignments and you don't need to be in class to do the first two, but it would be tough to find anyone who didn't devote a ton of time to this class. Rubin excels in exciting his students about the subject matter and making them eager to explore their own built environments. I really enjoyed my section; LiWei brought great insight and did a good job pulling discussion from silence.

Strengths: interesting and relevant assignments, good TAs who all love architecture (most are arch school grad students, not art history students), Rubin as lecturer, not that much week to week work.
Weaknesses: You have to remember 120 buildings for the final. It's kind of annoying, but you just have to get a quizlet and start early in reading period.

Loved the material taught in class. That said, I only attended about 60% of lectures cause they were definitely not necessary to do well in the class. The sections were fine, but the discussion wasn't very high level at all which I was sort of bummed about. The readings were interesting for the most part.

This class could be mandatory for all Yale students, as it only does us good. The lectures are low-stress and high return, the assignments are not overly difficult but force you to engage more critically and inquisitively with the built world around you, and the exams are fair. The sections have both strengths and weaknesses: they are a great forum for discussing architecture in a smaller group, but I think the fact that some people have much more of a background in the content than others comes through during section.

This course was a low-stress way to engage with the history of American architecture & urbanism. Professor Rubin gave great lectures that complemented the weekly readings and was clearly passionate about and engaged with the subject matter every class. The assignments helped take what we were learning in class and put it to practice in our own research about different architectural trends. I enjoyed how Professor Rubin tied lessons back to examples of architecture here in New Haven, which has helped me look at the city in an entirely different light knowing the history of different buildings that I pass by on a daily basis. Often Professor Rubin tried to cram a lot into each one of his lectures so the last several slides would always get covered very quickly as he went over time, which was a downside to otherwise great lectures. I wish a little more time was given in the beginning of the course to understanding different architectural vocabulary, as much of the reading uses specific terminology when discussing buildings and structures that makes some parts of the readings hard to picture/engage with as a student not coming from an architectural background.

Lectures were very compelling. The two assignments were very fun to do since there was so much individual choice. It was hard to understand what you should take notes on in order to prepare for the final.

Strengths: the research assignment and paper, section, weekly reading responses forced me to read the material, lecture is interesting 
Weaknesses: if you miss a lecture, hard to make it up because the slides are mostly just pictures without words

The weekly readings are really well curated to supplement the lectures. The lectures are engaging, conversational, and encourage continued thought on the topic outside the classroom. The class is also very low-stress, which is a welcomed change of pace.
First half of the course was not that interesting; I would focus more of the content on later architecture

The learning process in this course is structured around a 4-pillared model: lectures, readings, section, and independent research. I found this to be highly effective in terms of facilitating learning as each part contributed to a particular kind of learning: lectures provided the core material and themes which created a stable background knowledge base with which to engage with the rest of the course; readings offered specific examples and more in-depth analysis of projects and movements related to the week's key theme; section allowed for  critical discussion and the consideration of a plurality of perspectives and opinions; and the independent research projects made the course material relevant and engaging to each specific student based on their interests. 
One weakness of this course is that I think the assignments (and especially the final exam) could have been made more challenging so as to encourage deeper engagement with the course from all students; although on the other hand the existing structure allowed different students to engage with the course at different levels depending on how much it interested them.

Strengths: well organized, easy communication 

Weaknesses: lack of written notes, extreme memorization required for final exam

Strengths: interesting lectures, fast paced, lots of visuals
Weaknesses: lots of reading, sometimes hard to follow, lecture slides are not very clear, tons of memorization

As reviews from past years indicate, the final does kind of suck. You have to memorize 126 images and their corresponding years/architects, but I suppose it's not unlike AP Art History, for those familiar with the format of the exam. That's probably the single weakness to this class, and I'm not even sure how that would be amended.
Otherwise, this class is PHENOMENAL. Professor Rubin is hands down one of the best professors at Yale. I looked forward to lecture every Monday and Wednesday, the assignments (two research-y projects) were enjoyable, and the material had so much Yale in it that you could take a walk and see a building from lecture.

Strengths: the course materials and lectures were usually very interesting, the instructor and teaching fellows were all knowledgeable in the material being taught. Weaknesses: The course was poorly organized in terms of tracking the students' improvement/ grasp of the material; in particular, since there was only one major exam in the course, it was difficult to know what to expect/ gauging if one actually had a clear understanding of the material in preparation for the final. I would suggest adding a midterm in order to avoid such issues.

The strength and weakness of the course is its breadth: covering all of American architecture and urbanism in a single semester is ambitious but valuable. While I wish there were more attention to indigenous building, vernacular styles, and the sociology of cities over time, it is also amazing to cover all the major movements in architecture in such a short time.

Strengths: Interesting content, fun lecture. Professor Rubin is a great lecturer. Small workload throughout the semester.

Weaknesses: Complex readings at times, too much content to memorize come the final.
Lectures are great! And communication between Professor Rubin and the TFs is pretty good, but I think section could be more structured and related to the lectures. I also enjoyed the assignments.

Lectures are relatively engaging but sometimes seemed slightly too specific. I was never sure if the class was meant as an overview or as a look at individual case studies. Readings were primarily about individual buildings or projects, so getting a big-picture view was sometimes difficult. Assingment #1 was difficult but super interesting, and Professor Rubin and the TFs provided wonderful support in researching/seeing Sanborns, etc. It felt like a very welcoming learning environment.
The readings are too long and not all necessary to read for lecture. If the readings were shortened, more students would be likely to read them.
TFs seemed to grade on different levels, which I found unfair
The lectures from about half-way through can seem to get less 'substantial' and there was a disconnect between the readings and the lectures due to some delays on the lecture side of things.
The final exam is a bit too much - we should be given the 100 buildings much earlier and memorize facts as we go.
The course was very methodically taught. It went based on a timeline from past to present, which made architectural concepts easier to learn when comparing them to history.

This course gives a mostly engaging introduction to architectural history. The main thing that would imprive the course would be giving an overview of the architectural movements/styles and vocabulary at the very start of the course. Since many students have no background in architecture, these terms can be very confusing.
The pacing of the course was relatively uneven, especially right before the final.

This was a wonderful course---Professor Rubin is very excited to share his insights with the class, and I never thought his lectures were dull. The class was well-organized and cohesive. However, the class was so broad that sometimes I felt that it couldn't decide if it was an American Studies course, an architecture course, or an art history course---yes it is cross-listed as all three, and I felt that sometimes that was to the detriment of the class overall.

The lecture was great but the class wouldn't be successful without a good TF and section group. Professor Rubin does a really fantastic job of introducing concepts and eras with prominent examples, but the section is what really made it stick for me.
There are no weaknesses. This was probably my favorite course at Yale ever.
The lectures were always interesting and the sections engaging. However, I wouldve preferred readings that more closely adhered to the material discussed in lectures.
This class has an amazing and engaging lecture and there is so much information learned over the semester.
The course was very engaging and I genuinely enjoyed coming to lecture each week. The assignments were also so unique and exciting because we were given so much liberty with our topics.

I thought class was totally really well, the assignments and exam and readings all worked very well together. The assignments allowed students to engage in anything that really interested them and do real research. The readings, classes, and sections all prepared me well for the exam and I genuinely learned a lot.

Lectures are absolutely fantasticProfessor Rubin makes each lecture feel like its own TED talk, yet with the overarching theme of the course tying each one together. Section can sometimes be boring, especially if people havent done the reading.

I think a strength of this course was the breadth of knowledge we gained in relation to the built environment. Every lecture taught me something new and interesting and the course readings helped understand at a deeper level the content Professor Rubin went over in class. One aspect of the class I really enjoyed was the focus on New Haven. New Haven proved a perfect cross-section of the different movements and trends in architectural history that we learned about in class. Through a hands-on project we were able to go look deeper into the built environment of New Haven and apply the insights we gained in class to a tangible object. 

I think one way the course could be improved would be to make the lectures longer. Often the professor had more content to go over than we had time in class, so we always were sort of catching up each lecture. I think if the lectures were an hour 15 minutes instead of 50 minutes long, much of this problem could be solved.
The section could serve more as a review for the class, as opposed to just an exploration of the broad themes. The final exam could also include less memorization and more analysis.
I at times was confused where we were in the class. In the future it would be nice if we were more clear about when and what we will be talking about.

The strength of this course was how well the lectures formed a cohesive narrative instead of just feeling like an amalgamation of buildings. I also really liked how the history of Yale and New Haven were integrated in the course and really enjoyed the two research projects we had to do. One way it could be improved is I wish more time had been dedicated to learning the necessary background knowledge in architecture. As someone who came in without any background in architecture, some of the material would have been a lot less confusing if we had a previous lecture just dedicated to defining relevant architecture terms and movements.

The lectures were always very entertaining and Elihu Rubin was always very charismatic in his talks. I think maybe the readings could have been more concise and better curated, because sometime it was hard to get through them and actually understand them.

Strengths: really interesting/fun lecture, very cool material, skills you can use in your daily life and for daily enjoyment
Weaknesses: section was often bland, and the readings were sometimes repetitive

Pretty easy as classes go but the minimal work allows you to really engage with the material if you are interested. I loved the format and the structure of assignments and appreciated that the readings were interesting but not totally necessary if you didn't have time/weren't interested

Very engaging and interesting content.
Wish there could have been parts of the lectures that were explained more in depth especially for first-time Architecture students.

The exam was too heavily based on slide ID's, which I did not think was a fair evaluation of what we learned in class. The class was heavily focused on overarching themes and then it seemed like Prof Rubin would intentionally teach us slide ID analysis just for the exam, while everything else was for the purpose of learning architectural themes.

this is majorly a survey class, so its really good at getting the big ideas/trends but not as good at really explaining the reasons behind them and doesnt really get into the details. we moved through content very quickly so it sometimes was hard to keep up, which is not a problem week-to-week because theres pretty much zero work (besides reading responses and 2 short assignments) but the studying for the final definitely can feel like a huge rock to scale

The lectures were fairly unorganized, which made it difficult to study when the final came around. I think it also made it more difficult to learn and retain the information in general because there were no clear themes throughout the lecture. Each lecture started with a list of "themes" but they were difficult to follow through all of the examples.

Prof. Rubin is an amazing lecturer! Lecture portion of the class was great. Assignments were also interesting and allowed students to pursue certain topics. It might be helpful to have like more frequent, small quizzes on building IDs so you don't have to cram everything in a the end of the semester for the final.
Super engaging lectures and topics, section not as helpful.

Prof. Rubin is a very engaging professor. At some points, he could do more to digest the material into coherent threads for the class. Reviewing themes as they develop across classes would be helpful. Making these themes more visible in the slides ratehr than simply relying on the ability to tie things in ad hoc with a spoken comment would be helpful.

I really liked Professor Rubin's push to have students engage with archival materials and New Haven museums / establishments. One of the strengths is the building assignment where students choose a single building in New Haven and find out as much as they can about it. This was a cool assignment because it allowed students to engage with the city. However, while Professor Rubin had suggested to go to the New Haven Museum to gain material for the project, I wish he would have been more explicit in how necessary the museum visit would be for the project since so much of the information needed was only available at the museum. 
I thought the lectures were very engaging and provided great deals of information. However, I thought the quantity of the readings was too much for a survey lecture, and many of the readings' content was far too specific on a single topic that was not later discussed at any point in detail throughout the course.
Grade essays out of more than 25 points!!!!  Instructor was very engaging.
This is an interesting class if you want to know more about the ways in which architecture shapes cities.
This is a pretty good fifth class. It's really a class on urbanism, though, rather than on architecture. The research project is well thought-out, and I learned a lot doing it.
Definitely recommend!!
Really interesting course, and I learned a lot about an area I knew very little about coming in. I think it has changed the way I look at and think about the city around me in a good way.

Yes, make sure you take this course within your time at Yale! The difficulty level compared to the knowledge you will gain is a no-brainer. This course is a great 5th class and Professor Rubin is one of the best lecturers I've ever seen.

No. The course has no logical progression meaning that unless you have an immense passion for architecture, it is almost impossible to actively engage with the material. I enjoyed some of the topics but hated the class because the topics were so poorly connected leaving students feeling lost.
Yes If youre willing to teach yourself a study guide at the end of the class. Essays are good and no midterm
Absolutely! Really engaging, all-encompassing (architecture, history, social impact all in one class)

Yeah. Elihu is a good lecturer but his lectures tend to drag. He's incredibly enthusiastic but it tends to weigh down his lectures, and it becomes confusing as to what you're supposed to be 'wowed' by and what's just basic knowledge. He also tends to spend excessive amounts of time on single topics, which can be grating when you don't know how important something is.
Yes! It was so interesting and will give you important skills in observation and urban understanding.
Yes definitely, regardless of if you've ever taken any architecture or urbanism course.
Anyone who doesn't recommend this class can go to hell.
yes - gives a really good overview of American architecture in a very relaxed learning environment

If interested in architecture yes. Many people think of it as a gut, and it can be in terms of workload. There are "required" readings, but you do not really need to do them or really go to class. The two assignments do not have much to do with the work done in class. Once you get to the final though, it's a lot of information, and having the knowledge from class and the readings would be very helpful and make the final easy.
I would recommend this course to other students if they want a different approach to art history through architecture.

I would recommend this class to others, especially when looking for a Humanities credit that has to do with American Studies or Urban Studies.  Professor Rubin makes the class engaging, even as if dense with detail - the detail becomes interesting when framed in the way that he accomplishes.

This class can be interestingespecially for the first few lectures. But I often found the material a bit repetitive, shrouded in the clouds of academic words and theory, and overall, feel a bit lost amidst the styles and components of architectural vocabulary. Good fifth class.
Na
yes - very good survey and intro to the topic. professor Rubin is fantastic
yes !!!!  great class, not too much work, very interesting
Yes.
Yes. Interesting material, lectures are cool. Manageable workload. Nice class if you're looking for a cool humanities. I wouldn't say this is a gut though.

Yes! A great survey and intro course for anyone, a great humanities credit at that. The assigned work (readings, two short papers, discussion section, section presentation) is never boring and always interesting, which makes the workload feel fun (and not a chore).

I would recommend every Yale student to take the course. Truly, I think it's so important that it should be a mandatory course for everyone. You'll get exposed to the canonical breadth of American Architecture and understand how our surroundings have been so intimately built, shaped, destroyed, and restructured through architects and people's interactions with buildings.
Definitely recommend. Everyone should take this class, especially if you want an opportunity to see more of New Haven.

Strong lecture class with relatively low work :)

Final is just a lot of memorization
Yes, it was very interesting to dive deep into the basis of architecture and see similarities and differences in building types.

YES! You will not look at buildings in the same way after. Prof. Rubin is an extremely dynamic lecturer. Yale has great resources in this area and this is an easy way to dip your toe in architecture. If you don't enjoy the class, it's possible to check out and still feel on top of the material.

Yes if you're interested in architecture and have taken art history/architecture classes before. Architecture language is often abstract and verbose, so many people who haven't taken hsar/arch classes before are put off by it. However, if you know what you're getting yourself into and enjoy it, then you will like the class. Rubin is a passionate lecturer makes the material come to life. The workload is manageable and the assignments are interesting.

This course was super fun and I loved going to lecture. The assignments were pretty easy and overall this ended up being my "for fun" class of the semester. This class is a great introduction to the architectural world around us, but don't go in expecting rigorous theory or anything like that (as I did).
Absolutely--it's not very stressful, the lectures are extremely engaging, and you'll learn how to better interact with the world around you.
I definitely recommend this to someone interested in learning about architecture and architectural history with a bit of American history and urban studies thrown in as well.
Yes, its a new way to learn about American history. I had never studied architecture before and had a great time in the class.
Yes!! The material is very interesting even with zero architectural background
Would definitely recommend this course to literally anyone! A fascinating and eye-opening series of narratives about how our built environment came to be.

Yes! This class is super fun and low-stress, but you also learn a lot about architecture and urbanism. It's conducted kind of like an art history class, so it was  interesting to see how themes in urbanism have evolved through history.

Take this course! The work load is not bad at all. The first half of the semester is not that interesting but the class gets super good after the first few lectures. Great introduction to architecture for any major. Section is run very chill.

I would absolutely recommend this course. The way that I see and experience New Haven has completely changed now that I have a greater understanding of the greater forces and social/political/economic influences that have shaped the way the city looks and functions today. This change in perspective has made me feel much more at home in New Haven while also inspiring a drive to critically engage with the systems that underlie the city and find ways to improve it for those who inhabit and visit the space. The course is equally accessible for those with a background in architecture/urbanism and those without, and the level of engagement is essentially up to you (you can get away without doing the readings, or going to lecture, if you wish - but you really are selling yourself short if you do). The freedom given in the assignments allows for active engagement with the material, and encourages learning more about New Haven in particular (through the building research project) as well as a topic of interest to you - which will allow you to uncover some hidden and probably very important history about a part of the built environment that matters to you (or has shaped you, or been shaped by you, in some way). As a last note, Prof. Rubin is also very engaging and approachable and genuinely interested in both teaching and learning more through students' work.
Yes, it was very interesting and stimulating.
Yes! Professor is very good and passionate and you learn about buildings that you see every day - even more so if youre from the northeast
Only take this class if the grading structure is changed such that the final exam does not count for 45% of your final grade.  Otherwise it sucks.

Yes, it is incredibly interesting and very different from other courses I've taken. There are very few assignments (2 projects/essays and 1 final) but there are a ton of weekly readings (which require a reading response every week). The final is a lot of straight up memorization that was a little excessive in my opinion, but in the end, I still think I learned a lot.

I would recommend this class to a student 100%. It's not too difficult (save for the final, which was manageable but tougher than the rest of the class would have indicated), Professor Rubin is a gem, and a lot of the material is from Yale so the class doesn't feel abstract or theoretical, as you can see tangible evidence of different architectural movements in the immediate built environment. This may not be universally true, but I feel like I walked away with a lot of information that made me value everyday buildings a lot more.
yes --- good intro class to american architecture

I would recommend this course to another student if they were already interested in the material that would be taught, as well as if they were prepared to do a fair amount of independent studying in order to properly learn the material.

HSAR 219 was a great introductory class on architecture. Prof. Rubin was fantastic, the material covered in class was interesting, and the assignments allowed you to explore themes that piqued your curiosity.

I would recommend this course to any student looking for a broad survey of architectural history in the United States or generally. It is a great introduction to the history of America, and to the history of architecture in the West; and it requires basically no previous knowledge of either one. It is geared towards newcomers to topics of architecture and urbanism.
Yes!
Yes, definitely. Especially if they have some interest in architecture.
Yes! Elihu is a great lecturer, and the course will change the way you think about the cities around you.

Sure. Professor Rubin is an engaging lecturer, and you'll learn some vocabulary and history that are great to know. Taking this class as a non-Arch major is a great example of what liberal arts education should be. Take it and learn a little bit about a fascinating subject. It's not a ton of workjust do the readings you find interesting, honestlyand you get out of it as much as you put into it.
Yes. The material is interesting, and there is a lot of room in the two projects to explore pieces of architecture that interest you.
Yes! There wasn't too much work, but the final contained a lot of memorization.
Yes, if interested in architecture/the built environment
I would highly recommend this course to another student since it was highly engaging and interesting. I loved the TFs and the professor.
Yes, if they're looking for a good intro course.
Yes! Great professor, interesting topics, engaging, and low workload !

I would absolutely recommend this course, I found the material so fascinating and helpful in understanding so much of why America is the way it is today. The workload is very manageable and the readings are pretty interesting anyway, and Professor Rubin is really one of the best lecturers I've had at Yale (I would honestly try to go to some lectures even if you don't take the course).
Yes
I think this is a great class. Even if youre not considering being an Arch major, I would recommend taking it. Its not too much work and really teaches you to look at your environment differently.
Yes. If you have any interest in architecture, definitely take the course. If you don't care about architecture at all, you should also still take this course.

I would totally recommend this course. It is really thought provoking and influences one to think differently about the ways the built environment influences society and vice versa. The course has really elevated my thinking.
Yes, I believe the skills and knowledge gleaned in this course would benefit any student.
Yes definitely whether they are an architecture major or not.

Absolutely, I genuinely really enjoyed this class. I learned so much and it was a great experience. Professor Rubin teaches with incredible passion. You can legitimately take a lot away from this class.

Yesalthough there are only a couple of assignments throughout the entire semester, the knowledge gleaned from the course will stick with you well after the final exam. This course not only teaches you about American architecture and urbanism but also serves as the basis for living a more intentional lifestyle, in which you begin to appreciate and understand the environment around you.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about the social history behind American architecture. As a student who is not majoring in architecture, I think this class was a great way to get involved in the field of study without having to delve into the technical aspects of design and modeling. After a semester I now view the buildings around me, whether in New Haven, New York, or back home, in a different light and have become interested the stories behind these constructions.
Yes very interesting for learning about art history all around you.
I would recommend this course to another student. It was a great survey of American architecture and I found the lectures to be very engaging.
No

If the student wants to start understanding urbanism and architecture, I think it's a very good course to choose. Always entertaining, engaging and the workload was never overwhelming. In fact, the projects were always interesting to do.

Yes, as someone who had never studied buildings or cities in an academic setting, it was really interesting to learn about the history of American architecture and urbanism. The class was not only extremely enjoyable but also made me much more knowledgeable about trends in architecture and urbanism.
Definitely! Engaging lectures but low workload - a dream!
Yes, if they are interested in Architecture/Art.

I would not recommend this course to people just looking for a humanities credit. I do not think that broad survey courses are good for that, and this class is definitely a broad survey course. I found it difficult to engage with the lectures and found section very boring.
I think this course is engaging because it tackles a seemingly specific subject, American Architecture, from many perspectives far beyond the physical forms.
Absolutely, amazing class - a must take even if you're not an architecture major!

yes if you want to get broad knowledge on american architectural and urban history! but if youre looking for more in depth analysis or anything along those lines you might be frustrated in this class!!

Absolutely! The content of this class is really interesting and relevant to everyone, regardless of major, and Prof. Elihu presents it in a really intriguing and engaging way. Workload is really manageable and you'll learn a lot.
Definitely!!! Wonderful lectures from Elihu and a lot of interesting and relevant material. Especially good to take at Yale and hear more about New Haven.
It's an awesome course that will stay with you the rest of your life.

I think this is a great course for someone looking for a general introduction to the history and art of architecture in America. Additionally, this is an awesome course for someone looking for an engaging lecture that does not require an extensive workload.
